author: Jonathan Walker
title: Business needs to know what the plan is to protect the economy, North East employers warn
text:
Business needs to know what the plan is to protect the economy, North East employers warn 16:27, 27 Jun 2016 16:28, 27 Jun 2016 By Jonathan Walker Chancellor George Osborne has been told that he needs to give businesses more detail to steady the ship Shares Comments Get daily news by email 
North East employers need to know what the plan is for making sure the UK’s economy stays strong following last week’s Brexit vote, the region’s business leaders have warned. 
James Ramsbotham, Chief Executive of North East England Chamber of Commerce, said: “What business so desperately needs is to know what the road-map is, where it’s taking us and what the timescale is.” 
He was speaking after Chancellor George Osborne attempted to steady nerves with a speech revealing that the Treasury had been working on a plan for Brexit for weeks. 
It followed criticism that he had appeared to go to ground following last week’s referendum, when the country voted to leave the European Union, leaving uncertainty about who was actually running the country. James Ramsbotham, Chief Executive of the North East Chamber of Commerce 
Prime Minister David Cameron announced plans to resign following the ballot, although he continues in office until a replacement Conservative leader is elected. The Tory 1922 Committee, which will oversee the election, has announced that a new party leader - who will become Prime Minister - will be in place by September 2 at the latest. 
Mr Ramsbotham praised Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, who delivered a reassuring statement on Friday shortly after the referendum result was announced. 
And the Chamber leader said he welcome the Chancellor’s comments, but added:”Although he tried to reassure people by saying there was a plan, I think we’d like to see the details of said plan. 
“What businesses need is to understand what that plan is, how long it might take, and to begin to get a feel of what it might look like.” 
He said: “Businesses may not like it, but they can cope with anything as long as they know what it is. 
“But if there is a plan, nobody seems to know what it is - or not well enough to communicate it.” 
In his speech, Mr Osborne insisted: “I want to reassure the British people, and the global community, that Britain is ready to confront what the future holds for us from a position of strength. Chancellor George Osborne 
“That is because in the last six years the government and the British people have worked hard to rebuild the British economy.” 
While he had campaigned for a remain vote, everyone had to accept that the public had voted to leave the European Union, Mr Osborne said. 
“The Treasury, the Bank of England, and the Financial Conduct Authority have spent the last few months putting in place robust contingency plans for the immediate financial aftermath in the event of this result.” 
He said the Treasury and the Prudential Regulation Authority, a Bank of England body which regulates banks, had “worked systematically with each major financial institution in recent weeks to make sure they were ready to deal with the consequences of a vote to leave.” 
Mr Osborne added: “It will not be plain sailing in the days ahead, but let me be clear. You should not underestimate our resolve. 
“We were prepared for the unexpected. We are equipped for whatever happens.” 
He made no direct mention of plans for an “emergency budget” - despite warning during the referendum campaign that a vote for Brexit would force him to raise taxes and cut public spending. 
But he appeared to hint that some action would be required, saying: “It is already evident that as a result of Thursday’s decision, some firms are continuing to pause their decisions to invest, or to hire people. 
“As I said before the referendum, this will have an impact on the economy and the public finances – and there will need to be action to address that.” 
Sterling continued its steep slide against the dollar on Monday as concerns about the British economy deepened. 
The pound plunged 3.35% against the US currency to 1.32 dollars, following on from Friday’s 10% dive. 
Against the euro the pound was also down, falling 2.27% at 1.20 euro. 
Mr Osborne’s speech had contributed to a mini-rally early on Monday, but the gains soon evaporated and experts warned that months of uncertainty could see more volatility.
